awd_titl_txt: A Helioseismic Study of Active Region Flows and their Contribution to Global Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The survey to be produced as part of this 3-year project will considerably increase our knowledge about the physics of subsurface flows inside the Sun, allowing their variation with magnetic region properties, and with time, to be ascertained.  The research program seeks to understand how these flows affect larger circulation patterns, particularly the meridional and zonal flow components of global circulation.  The meridional flow is involved critically in the process that leads to Sun's polar field polarity reversals and the ability to predict properties of subsequent solar cycles.  It is not clear how it is modulated in time by the contribution of active-region related inflows.  A quantitative assessment of this contribution, provided by this research project, will allow critical improvements to be made in predictive models.  Theories regarding the physics of the flows have been put forward, with predictions about their variation with depth.  These predictions will be tested by the inverse modeling efforts as part of this project.  Using artificial data available from numerical MHD simulations, the research activities will also aim to develop and validate methods to infer subsurface flows reliably and which avoid artifacts caused by the influence of surface magnetic fields on the seismic waves.  These methods will be invaluable for improving and validating other models of flows and structures inferred through helioseismology.

The main purpose of this 3-year project is to perform a comprehensive, high-spatial-resolution helioseismic survey of subsurface flows around solar magnetic regions in order to improve models of solar dynamo.  The research project has four main objectives. The first objective is to characterize, using helioseismic holography applied to Dopplergrams from the Helioseismic Imager onboard the SDO mission, the near-surface flows observed around solar active regions.  This characterization will include examining the dependence of the flow properties with magnetic flux.  The time dependence of the flows as regions evolve will also be examined.  The second objective is to establish and quantify the contribution of the near-surface flows surrounding active regions to the latitudinal- and temporal-variation of the global meridional and zonal flow patterns.  This will be achieved by comparing monthly time and longitude averages of active-region related flows with meridional and zonal flow measurements.  The third objective is to determine, through helioseismic inverse modeling, the depth dependence of active-region related flows, in order to provide a physical understanding of the flows.  The fourth objective is to validate the reliability of the flow determination around active regions.  This will be achieved using existing synthetic data derived from state-of-the-art numerical MHD simulations of waves in the vicinity of magnetic structures.

An understanding of the contribution of active-region-related flows in Sun's interior to the larger-scale dynamics is required for improving surface-flux-transport models of the solar dynamo.  The outcome of this project is expected to improve general knowledge of solar and stellar dynamos and the evolution of magnetic fields.  The expected results will allow improvements in predicting the solar-cycles of the Sun.  The project team will broadly disseminate data products for their use in these types of models as part of this program.  This project will facilitate continued involvement of the team in the REU Program in Solar and Space Physics hosted by the University of Colorado at Boulder.  A considerable portion of this research is being carried out by a postdoctoral research scientist who will take the lead on several of the project tasks.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

por.por_cntn:
Appearing on the surface of the Sun are plasma motions, some of which are random and convective and others which are related in complicated ways to the presence of strong magnetic fields. Those fields, such as those that form sunspots, may themselves be generated with the help of flows within the interior of the Sun.  The first main component of the research is to carry out a survey of plasma flows near solar magnetic regions.  Extending a survey which was initiated by the researchers under a prior NSF grant they used public data from the NASA Solar Dynamics Observer mission and the method of helioseismic holography. This method uses sound waves in the interior of Sun to measure flows in a way analogous to how Doppler-radar techniques can measure wind speed on Earth.  Over 5000 flow measurements of 336 magnetic regions observed between 2010 and 2014 were made. To decrease noise, the method of ensemble averaging was used. This method averages flow fields over subsets (ensembles) of regions sorted on the basis of the total magnetic flux of the region.  These averages show converging flows with speeds of approximately 10 m/s and extending up to 10 angular degrees from the magnetic region centers. These inflows are prevalent and have similar properties for all regions with magnetic flux above 1021 Mx. Retrograde flows, which move in the opposite direction of solar rotation, are also discovered with amplitudes around 10 m/s. These retrograde flows flank predominantly, but not exclusively, the side of the regions closer to the Sun's pole.  The first Figure accompanying this report shows two example ensemble averages for ensembles of magnetic regions with alternately weak and strong magnetic fluxes.

The second main component of this work is to understand how these magnetic region flows contribute to global averages of the Sun's flow field which are themselves used to understand and predict the long-term properties of the solar cycle.  The researchers estimated the expected contribution of these magnetic-region flows to averages over longitude and time of the zonal (along lines of longitude) and meridional (along lines of latitude) flow components of the global averages.  The results demonstrate that the magnetic-region flows are responsible for at least some component of the time-varying global flows.  For the meridional component, the perturbations to the mean meridional circulation take the form of converging zones centered (at least approximately) on the mean latitudes of activity, which is qualitatively consistent with the observed variations of meridional circulation observed when the Sun is very magnetically active. The retrograde flows, discovered in this project, also appear to give rise to some of the so-called torsional oscillation which is observed in the zonal component of the global flows.

A third component of this work is to validate the methods, particularly helioseismic holography, used by the researchers to measure flows just beneath the Sun's surface. This was accomplished with the use of artificial data, constructed using numerical simulations, in which one can compare a known property of the simulation with what is extracted using holography.  Much of this work was carried out by a young post-doctoral researcher hired immediately out of graduate school. Findings included a good match between the true flow field in the vicinity of an artificial sunspot and what was inferred from the methods developed in this project (see the second Figure for an example). But differences are also instructive, since they indicate where the presence of magnetic fields inside sunspots may complicate inferences of flows.

The physics of the Sun is explored both to understand how it compares with other stars and objects the universe and also to try to understand and predict how things like solar flares and other events on the Sun effect the Earth and society.  The impacts of the research described here include examples which align with both motives. For example, one need to understand flows on other stars in order to use the stellar velocity signals accurately enough to detect Earth-sized planets around them. Using the Sun as a guide can provide estimates of how this may be achieved and one study was proposed and funded by NASA as a result of the findings in this research.   Understanding flows on the Sun also enhances our ability to make predictions about how frequently to expect future solar events. Researchers will be able to use the flow fields measured here in models of how magnetic fields are transported over the course of the eleven year solar magnetic cycle. These models have the potential of predicting the strength and duration of future magnetic cycles.
